information:
Economic challenges and trade policy are key sources of market uncertainty. Tariffs imposed by the Trump administration have led to downward revisions of corporate earnings expectations. A Goldman Sachs model predicts that a 5% increase in tariffs could lead to a 1-2% decline in S&P 500 earnings per share. Sevens Report notes that even with reduced trade tensions, the base level of tariffs will remain much higher than in January, acting as a barrier to growth and a driver of inflation. Analysts at Barclays have expressed skepticism about whether there is enough momentum in U.S.-China trade discussions to avoid a U.S. recession.

In the week ending April 25, 2025, the S&P 500 index rose 4.6% to close at 5,525.21, its best weekly performance of the year to date. The Nasdaq Composite saw a 6.7% increase and the Dow Jones rose 2.5% during the same period. This rally was led by a recovery in large technology stocks. Despite the recent gains, market valuations are elevated, with the price-to-earnings ratio for the S&P 500 cited as being between 19 and 28, above historical averages. The VIX, a measure of market volatility, was recently observed at a high level of approximately 25.

Several market-moving events are scheduled for late April and early May 2025. Major technology companies, including Microsoft, Meta, Apple, and Amazon, are set to release their first-quarter earnings reports. In total, over 180 S&P 500 companies are expected to report. Key economic data releases are also imminent, including the report on first-quarter GDP growth, the Personal Consumer Expenditures (PCE) inflation gauge for March, the ISM Manufacturing Index for April, and the April employment report. The Federal Reserve's next policy meeting is scheduled for May 7.

forecast.time_left_until_outcome_known: About 1 month (until the May 30, 2025 close; Yahoo finalizes within hours to a day).
forecast.status_quo_outcome: Slightly up month (May closes a bit above April’s final close).
forecast.no_outcome_scenario: Inflation data (e.g., April CPI mid‑May) runs hot and the Fed on May 7 sounds more hawkish about stickiness; 10-year yields push higher, mega-cap earnings/guidance disappoint, and renewed tariff headlines revive growth and margin fears. S&P fades and finishes May below April’s close.
forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: Mega-cap earnings are solid with resilient guidance; April CPI/PPI cool, bond yields ease, and the Fed maintains a steady/dovish tone. Risk appetite improves and the S&P grinds higher into month-end, closing above April’s final print.
forecast.rationale: Base-rate first: historically the S&P 500 finishes up in a given month roughly 55–60% of the time; May specifically is positive a little over half the time. That alone leans modestly to “Yes.” The current setup adds two-sided risk. On one hand: (1) Earnings season concentrated in mega-cap tech can be a positive catalyst; (2) a recent rebound into late April suggests momentum tailwinds if data cooperate; (3) if inflation cools and yields ease, valuation pressure abates. On the other hand: (1) Valuations are elevated (P/E cited 19–28), leaving less cushion; (2) volatility is high (VIX ~25), implying wider tails; (3) policy/trade uncertainty and tariffs can pressure margins and keep inflation sticky, limiting multiple expansion; (4) a hawkish-leaning Fed tone on May 7 would weigh on equities. From the research assistant: tariffs are a persistent overhang that trim EPS and keep inflation higher; analysts are skeptical on growth momentum; late April saw a sharp rally (S&P +4.6% for the week to Apr 25) led by big tech, but valuations remain rich and many market-moving events cluster in late Apr/early May (earnings, GDP, PCE, ISM, jobs, Fed). Weighing these, I put extra weight on the status quo/base rate (world changes slowly), but haircut it for elevated valuations, policy uncertainty, and recent volatility. That yields a modestly-above-even chance of an up month. Why not higher: rich valuations, high VIX, rate/inflation event risk, and tariff/policy noise. Why not lower: base-rate seasonality, potential for earnings beats from mega-caps, and the possibility that inflation data softens and yields retreat. What would shift me up: broadly strong mega-cap results and guidance, cooler April CPI/PPI and payrolls, and a market-friendly Fed tone—especially if the April 30 close isn’t at a new high. What would shift me down: hot inflation and/or strong wage growth, a hawkish Fed, notable mega-cap misses, 10-year yields pushing materially higher, or escalation on tariff policy.

prompt:
You are a professional forecaster interviewing for a job.

Your interview question is:
Will the S&P 500 index go up in May 2025?

Question background:
NY Times: [What Is a Bear Market? Are We in One?](https://www.nytimes.com/article/bear-market-stocks-tariffs.html)


This question's outcome will be determined by the specific criteria below. These criteria have not yet been satisfied:
This question will resolve as Yes if the closing value of the S&P 500 Index on the final trading day of May 2025 is higher than that of the final trading day of April 2025.

The "close" values shown on the [history page of Yahoo finance](https://finance.yahoo.com/quote/%5EGSPC/history?p=%5EGSPC) will be used.


Your research assistant's report says:
Economic challenges and trade policy are key sources of market uncertainty. Tariffs imposed by the Trump administration have led to downward revisions of corporate earnings expectations. A Goldman Sachs model predicts that a 5% increase in tariffs could lead to a 1-2% decline in S&P 500 earnings per share. Sevens Report notes that even with reduced trade tensions, the base level of tariffs will remain much higher than in January, acting as a barrier to growth and a driver of inflation. Analysts at Barclays have expressed skepticism about whether there is enough momentum in U.S.-China trade discussions to avoid a U.S. recession.

In the week ending April 25, 2025, the S&P 500 index rose 4.6% to close at 5,525.21, its best weekly performance of the year to date. The Nasdaq Composite saw a 6.7% increase and the Dow Jones rose 2.5% during the same period. This rally was led by a recovery in large technology stocks. Despite the recent gains, market valuations are elevated, with the price-to-earnings ratio for the S&P 500 cited as being between 19 and 28, above historical averages. The VIX, a measure of market volatility, was recently observed at a high level of approximately 25.

Several market-moving events are scheduled for late April and early May 2025. Major technology companies, including Microsoft, Meta, Apple, and Amazon, are set to release their first-quarter earnings reports. In total, over 180 S&P 500 companies are expected to report. Key economic data releases are also imminent, including the report on first-quarter GDP growth, the Personal Consumer Expenditures (PCE) inflation gauge for March, the ISM Manufacturing Index for April, and the April employment report. The Federal Reserve's next policy meeting is scheduled for May 7.

Today is 2025-04-29.

Before answering you think:
(a) The time left until the outcome to the question is known.
(b) The status quo outcome if nothing changed.
(c) A brief description of a scenario that results in a No outcome.
(d) A brief description of a scenario that results in a Yes outcome.
(e) You write your rationale remembering that good forecasters put extra weight on the status quo outcome since the world changes slowly most of the time. Explain your reasoning and the evidence behind your forecast in detail. Summarise information your received from your research assistant that influences your forecast (if any). Explain why your forecast is not higher, and why it is not lower. Outline what would need to be true for you to update your forecast in either direction.
(f) The last thing you write is your final probabilistic forecast as a number between 0 and 100.

# OUTPUT SCHEMA
{
    "time_left_until_outcome_known": "string",
    "status_quo_outcome": "string",
    "no_outcome_scenario": "string",
    "yes_outcome_scenario": "string",
    "rationale": "string",
    "probability": "number" (0-100)
}
